DOC.HEAD: U.S. Occupiers Get Mixed Reaction in Panama City
With PM-Panama, Bjt
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Panamanians greeted occupying U.S. forces with some cheers and some sneers but mostly fear, and many remained at home rather than risk exposure in glass-littered streets swarming with looters. Some of those who did venture out expressed hopes only that the bloodshed and destruction would cease. Businessman Moises Levi pointed at his looted store and then at an American soldier standing atop a nearby armored personnel carrier. ``How many soldiers are there here, 20,000, 40,000? Where are they?'' he asked. Mayhem and destruction have descended on the city since U.S. troops began their invasion at midnight Tuesday. Knots of fighters backing ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega have attacked, then disappeared, while shopkeepers trade shots with swarms of looters. ``They really screwed me up as a businessman,'' said bicycle shop owner Ivan Rios. ``As a Panamanian, I am opposed to this type of military action against my country, but I am also glad that at last we are going to have democracy.'' Many Panamanians were too frightened to come out of their homes and display any emotion about the events that rocked their Central American country, but some did cheer Americans stationed around the Nicaraguan Embassy. Streets in this city of 1 million people were layered with broken glass, overturned trash cans and fallen light poles. Plumes of smoke darkened the sky where gunfire and mortar attacks were launched. Two American officers escorted by a dozen American GIs in battle gear toured the Santo Tomas Hospital. Deputy director Dr. Elmer Miranda said they were ``on an inspection'' of the building. Miranda criticized the Americans because, in addition to dead and wounded, the assault created a shortage of food and all types of medicines. He said the closing of airports was preventing aid from entering the country. One administrative employee hurrying along a corridor also chastized the American action. ``They are butchering us. We don't want any help from them,'' she said. ``The United States are courageous with Panama, but they do not dare meddle with Russia or Japan.'' Out on the streets, though, a busload of civilians passing by the Nicaraguan Embassy on Friday morning waved white handkerchiefs and cheered the U.S. soldiers standing by their armored cars. The Americans, who cordoned off the embassy following rumors that Noriega was there, smiled and waved back. Marine Lance Cpl. Tracy Scott Jones of Dallas said that after the shock of the first day's battle, ``People were cheering us on. They are on our side. They clapped as we rolled through the streets. There was no hostility.'' Lance Cpl. William Young of Seattle said civilians were ``friendly. They give us the thumbs up sign.'' ``When you go out on a mission at night the situation is pretty tense. You just look at the darkness and all you can see are the shapes of people,'' said Young. ``But, then when you go out in the day, people are pretty friendly.''
